description.text: RNA Secondary Structure Prediction and Comparison.

doc.title: RNAup

description.text: Calculate the thermodynamics of RNA-RNA interactions

doc.authors: Ivo L Hofacker, Peter F Stadler, Stephan Bernhart
doc.reference: I.L. Hofacker, W. Fontana, P.F. Stadler, S. Bonhoeffer, M. Tacker, P. Schuster (1994) Fast Folding and Comparison of RNA Secondary Structures. Monatshefte f. Chemie 125: 167-188
S.H.Bernhart, Ch. Flamm, P.F. Stadler, I.L. Hofacker Partition Function and Base Pairing Probabilities of RNA Heterodimers Algorithms Mol. Biol. (2006)
D.H. Mathews, J. Sabina, M. Zuker and H. Turner "Expanded Sequence Dependence of Thermodynamic Parameters Provides Robust Prediction of RNA Secondary Structure" JMB, 288, pp 911-940, 1999

comment.text: RNAup calculates the thermodynamics of RNA-RNA interactions, by decomposing the binding into two stages.
(1) First the probability that a potential binding sites remains unpaired (equivalent to the free energy needed to open the site) is computed.
(2) Then this accessibility is combined with the interaction energy to obtain the total binding energy.
All calculations are done by computing partition functions over all possible conformations.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Each line of file corresponds to one sequence, except for lines starting with ">" which contain the name of the next sequence. To compute the hybrid structure of two molecules, the two sequences must be concatenated using the & character as separator.
xhtml:div.div:
Example data (click on [use example data] to load):
ACGAUCAGAGAUCAGAGCAUACGACAGCAG&ACGAAAAAAAGAGCAUACGACAGCAG

fieldset.legend: Options for calculation of free energies

xhtml:div.label:
Specifies the length of the unstructured region (-u)?
Specifies the length (len) of the unstructured region in the output. The default value is 4. The probability of being unpaired is plotted on the right border of the unpaired region. You can specify up to 20 different length values: use "-" to specify a range of continuous values (e.g. -u 4-8) or specify a list of comma separated values (e.g. -u 4,8,15).

Option allows to get the different contributions to the probability of being unpaired. (-c)?
by default only the full probability of being unpaired is plot- ted. The -c option allows to get the different contributions (c) to the probability of being unpaired: The full probability of being unpaired ("S") is the sum of the probability of being unpaired in the exterior loop ("E"), within a hairpin loop ("H"), within an interior loop ("I") and within a multiloop ("M"). Any combination of these letters may be given.

Determines the maximal length of the region of interaction (-w)?
Determines the maximal length of the region of interaction, the default is 25.

Include the probability of unpaired regions in both RNAs (-b)?
Yes No
Include the probability of unpaired regions in both (b) RNAs. By default only the probability of being unpaired in the longer RNA (target) is used.

Extend the region of interaction in the target by len residues to the 5' side?
These options extend the region of interaction in the target by len residues to the 5' and 3' side, respectively. The underlying assumption is that it is favorable for an interaction if not only the direct region of contact is unpaired but also a few residues 5' and 3' of this region.

Extend the region of interaction in the target by len residues to the 3' side?
These options extend the region of interaction in the target by len residues to the 5' and 3' side, respectively. The underlying assumption is that it is favorable for an interaction if not only the direct region of contact is unpaired but also a few residues 5' and 3' of this region.

Interaction mode?
Pairwise interaction is calculated (-Xp) The interaction of each sequence with the first one is calculated (-Xf)
Xp: Pairwise (p) interaction is calculated: The first sequence interacts with the 2nd, the third with the 4th etc. If -Xp is selected two interacting sequences may be given in a single line separated by "&" or each sequence may be given on an extra line.
Xf: The interaction of each sequence with the first one is calculated (e.g. interaction of one mRNA with many small RNAs). Each sequence has to be given on an extra line.

Use the first sequence in the input file as the target?
Yes No
Use the first sequence in the input file as the target. No length check is done
Rescale energy parameters to a temperature of temp C. (-T)
Do not include special stabilizing energies for certain tetraloops (-4) Yes No

How to treat dangling end energies for bases adjacent to helices in free ends and multiloops (-d)?
Only unpaired bases can participate in at most one dangling end (-d1) Ignores dangling ends altogether (-d) The check is ignored, this is the default for partition function folding. (-d2)
How to treat 'dangling end' energies for bases adjacent to helices in free ends and multiloops: Normally only unpaired bases can participate in at most one dangling end. With -d2 this check is ignored, this is the default for partition function folding (-p). -d ignores dangling ends altogether. Note that by default pf and mfe folding treat dangling ends differently, use -d2 (or -d) in addition to -p to ensure that both algorithms use the same energy model. The -d2 options is available for RNAfold, RNAeval, and RNAinverse only.

Use scale*mfe as an estimate for the free energy (-S)?
In the calculation of the pf use scale*mfe as an estimate for the ensemble free energy (used to avoid overflows). The default is 1.07, usefull values are 1.0 to 1.2. Occasionally needed for long sequences. You can also recompile the programm to use double precision (see the README file).

Avoid lonely pairs (helices of length 1) (-noLP)?
Yes No
Produce structures without lonely pairs (helices of length 1). For partition function folding this only disallows pairs that can only occur isolated. Other pairs may still occasionally occur as helices of length 1.
Do not allow GU pairs (-noGU) Yes No
Do not allow GU pairs at the end of helices (-noCloseGU) Yes No

Non standard pairs (comma seperated list) (-nsp)?
Allow other pairs in addition to the usual AU,GC,and GU pairs. pairs is a comma seperated list of additionally allowed pairs. If a the first character is a '-' then AB will imply that AB and BA are allowed pairs. e.g. RNAfold -nsp -GA will allow GA and AG pairs. Nonstandard pairs are given 0 stacking energy.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Read energy parameters from paramfile, instead of using the default parameter set. A sample parameterfile should accompany your distribution. See the RNAlib documentation for details on the file format.

Each line of file corresponds to one sequence, except for lines starting with ">" which contain the name of the next sequence. To compute the hybrid structure of two molecules, the two sequences must be concatenated using the & character as separator.

xhtml:fieldset.xhtml:legend: Options for calculation of free energies

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Specifies the length (len) of the unstructured region in the output. The default value is 4. The probability of being unpaired is plotted on the right border of the unpaired region. You can specify up to 20 different length values: use "-" to specify a range of continuous values (e.g. -u 4-8) or specify a list of comma separated values (e.g. -u 4,8,15).

by default only the full probability of being unpaired is plot- ted. The -c option allows to get the different contributions (c) to the probability of being unpaired: The full probability of being unpaired ("S") is the sum of the probability of being unpaired in the exterior loop ("E"), within a hairpin loop ("H"), within an interior loop ("I") and within a multiloop ("M"). Any combination of these letters may be given.
Determines the maximal length of the region of interaction, the default is 25.
Include the probability of unpaired regions in both (b) RNAs. By default only the probability of being unpaired in the longer RNA (target) is used.

These options extend the region of interaction in the target by len residues to the 5' and 3' side, respectively. The underlying assumption is that it is favorable for an interaction if not only the direct region of contact is unpaired but also a few residues 5' and 3' of this region.

These options extend the region of interaction in the target by len residues to the 5' and 3' side, respectively. The underlying assumption is that it is favorable for an interaction if not only the direct region of contact is unpaired but also a few residues 5' and 3' of this region.

Xp: Pairwise (p) interaction is calculated: The first sequence interacts with the 2nd, the third with the 4th etc. If -Xp is selected two interacting sequences may be given in a single line separated by "&" or each sequence may be given on an extra line.
Xf: The interaction of each sequence with the first one is calculated (e.g. interaction of one mRNA with many small RNAs). Each sequence has to be given on an extra line.
Use the first sequence in the input file as the target. No length check is done

How to treat 'dangling end' energies for bases adjacent to helices in free ends and multiloops: Normally only unpaired bases can participate in at most one dangling end. With -d2 this check is ignored, this is the default for partition function folding (-p). -d ignores dangling ends altogether. Note that by default pf and mfe folding treat dangling ends differently, use -d2 (or -d) in addition to -p to ensure that both algorithms use the same energy model. The -d2 options is available for RNAfold, RNAeval, and RNAinverse only.

In the calculation of the pf use scale*mfe as an estimate for the ensemble free energy (used to avoid overflows). The default is 1.07, usefull values are 1.0 to 1.2. Occasionally needed for long sequences. You can also recompile the programm to use double precision (see the README file).

Produce structures without lonely pairs (helices of length 1). For partition function folding this only disallows pairs that can only occur isolated. Other pairs may still occasionally occur as helices of length 1.

Allow other pairs in addition to the usual AU,GC,and GU pairs. pairs is a comma seperated list of additionally allowed pairs. If a the first character is a '-' then AB will imply that AB and BA are allowed pairs. e.g. RNAfold -nsp -GA will allow GA and AG pairs. Nonstandard pairs are given 0 stacking energy.

Read energy parameters from paramfile, instead of using the default parameter set. A sample parameterfile should accompany your distribution. See the RNAlib documentation for details on the file format.

parameter.name: partition_free
parameter.prompt: Specifies the length of the unstructured region (-u)

format.code: ( "" , " -u "+ str(value) )[ value is not None and value != vdef ]

comment.text: Specifies the length (len) of the unstructured region in the output. The default value is 4. The probability of being unpaired is plotted on the right border of the unpaired region. You can specify up to 20 different length values: use "-" to specify a range of continuous values (e.g. -u 4-8) or specify a list of comma separated values (e.g. -u 4,8,15).

parameter.name: dangling
parameter.prompt: How to treat dangling end energies for bases adjacent to helices in free ends and multiloops (-d)

velem.label: Only unpaired bases can participate in at most one dangling end (-d1)
The check is ignored, this is the default for partition function folding. (-d2)

format.code: ( "" , " " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value != vdef]

comment.text: How to treat 'dangling end' energies for bases adjacent to helices in free ends and multiloops: Normally only unpaired bases can participate in at most one dangling end. With -d2 this check is ignored, this is the default for partition function folding (-p). -d ignores dangling ends altogether. Note that by default pf and mfe folding treat dangling ends differently, use -d2 (or -d) in addition to -p to ensure that both algorithms use the same energy model. The -d2 options is available for RNAfold, RNAeval, and RNAinverse only.

interface.label:

Only unpaired bases can participate in at most one dangling end (-d1) Ignores dangling ends altogether (-d) The check is ignored, this is the default for partition function folding. (-d2)

The -d2 options is available for RNAfold, RNAeval, and RNAinverse only.

parameter.name: scale
parameter.prompt: Use scale*mfe as an estimate for the free energy (-S)

comment.text: In the calculation of the pf use scale*mfe as an estimate for the ensemble free energy (used to avoid overflows). The default is 1.07, usefull values are 1.0 to 1.2. Occasionally needed for long sequences. You can also recompile the programm to use double precision (see the README file).

interface.label:
Use scale*mfe as an estimate for the free energy (-S)?

comment.text: Produce structures without lonely pairs (helices of length 1). For partition function folding this only disallows pairs that can only occur isolated. Other pairs may still occasionally occur as helices of length 1.

parameter.prompt: Do not allow GU pairs (-noGU)

parameter.name: noCloseGU

parameter.name: nsp
parameter.prompt: Non standard pairs (comma seperated list) (-nsp)

comment.text: Allow other pairs in addition to the usual AU,GC,and GU pairs. pairs is a comma seperated list of additionally allowed pairs. If a the first character is a '-' then AB will imply that AB and BA are allowed pairs. e.g. RNAfold -nsp -GA will allow GA and AG pairs. Nonstandard pairs are given 0 stacking energy.

parameter.name: parameter
parameter.prompt: Energy parameter file (-P)
